content:
Attachment II-A Audit Report No. 1 .- 1711
MC- 2747
February 20, 1962
Mr. K. T. Li Secretary General Council for United States Aid Taipei, Taiwan
Dear Mr. Li:
This afternoon I took a quick look at the status of excess property receipts and allocation by means of a visit to the BES and Taiwan Supply Bureau warehouses. We were accompanied by Mr. Tan of your staff. A more detailed account of our observations and proposals for correction of certain deficiencies will be forwarded to you shortly. However, there are a few matters of immediate concern on which I believe you should be informed so that necessary remedial action can be undertaken:
First, I was most surprised and dismayed to be told that a number of the usable smaller machine tools on hand at the TSB warehouse have been allocated to the 61st Arsenal and to other MND production facilities. Military utiliz ation of excess equipment and materials procured under economic aid financing is definitely not appropriate. I trust that CUSA will take immediate steps to countermand all allocations which have been made to the MND.
0
Second, the storage conditions for a number of valuable machine tools are quite unsatisfactory. The housekeeping situation at the BES is particularly messy, and we observed three or four lathes, boring machines drill presses, etc., unprotected from the weather and often dumped haphazardly on the ground. Conditions at the TSB warehouse were somewhat better, in that most of the large machine tools stored cutside were at least covered with tarpaulins. However, a few of these tools were unprotected and all of them are in a somewhat exposed situation.
Third, in spite of the fact that procurement of excess under more recent PIO's was conditioned on CUS/.'s making arrangements to dispose of excess items already on hand, we observed a number of crates at the BES warehouse which had been standing around unopened (and apparently not yet allocated) for over a year.
Fourth, the last batch of non-project excess procured by CUSA representatives in the United States includes a number of large, and in some cases highly specialized, machine tools. Examples of this type are heavy boring machines and some machines for multiple boring of engine cylinders. Unless end-users can be located for this specialized equipment, it may well end up as scrap - the fate we were told is in store for two large crankshaft grinders which have been sitting in the BES yard for ma ny months.
In arranging to make this inspection trip, I found that CUSA was to or three months in arrears on reporting status of excess arrivals and allocations in compliance with arrangements agreed to with the Mission. I would hope that this reporting delinquency, together with corrective actions on the points mentioned above, can be attended to at your earliest convenience.
Sincerely yours,
R. L. Kirchberg Program Officer 國史饭 Academia Historica
78

lines.content: Attachment II-A
Audit Report No. 1 .- 1711
February 20, 1962
Mr. K. T. Li
Secretary General
Council for United States Aid
Taipei, Taiwan
Dear Mr. Li:
This afternoon I took a quick look at the status of excess property
receipts and allocation by means of a visit to the BES and Taiwan Supply
Bureau warehouses. We were accompanied by Mr. Tan of your staff. A more
detailed account of our observations and proposals for correction of
certain deficiencies will be forwarded to you shortly. However, there are
a few matters of immediate concern on which I believe you should be
informed so that necessary remedial action can be undertaken:

the usable smaller machine tools on hand at the TSB warehouse have been
allocated to the 61st Arsenal and to other MND production facilities.
Military utiliz ation of excess equipment and materials procured under
economic aid financing is definitely not appropriate. I trust that CUSA
will take immediate steps to countermand all allocations which have been
made to the MND.
Second, the storage conditions for a number of valuable machine tools
are quite unsatisfactory. The housekeeping situation at the BES is

and all of them are in a somewhat exposed situation.
Third, in spite of the fact that procurement of excess under more
recent PIO's was conditioned on CUS/.'s making arrangements to dispose of
excess items already on hand, we observed a number of crates at the BES
warehouse which had been standing around unopened (and apparently not
yet allocated) for over a year.
Fourth, the last batch of non-project excess procured by CUSA
representatives in the United States includes a number of large, and in
some cases highly specialized, machine tools. Examples of this type are

cylinders. Unless end-users can be located for this specialized

convenience.
Sincerely yours,
R. L. Kirchberg
Program Officer
國史饭
Academia Historica

paragraphs.content: Mr. K. T. Li Secretary General Council for United States Aid Taipei, Taiwan

This afternoon I took a quick look at the status of excess property receipts and allocation by means of a visit to the BES and Taiwan Supply Bureau warehouses. We were accompanied by Mr. Tan of your staff. A more detailed account of our observations and proposals for correction of certain deficiencies will be forwarded to you shortly. However, there are a few matters of immediate concern on which I believe you should be informed so that necessary remedial action can be undertaken:

First, I was most surprised and dismayed to be told that a number of the usable smaller machine tools on hand at the TSB warehouse have been allocated to the 61st Arsenal and to other MND production facilities. Military utiliz ation of excess equipment and materials procured under economic aid financing is definitely not appropriate. I trust that CUSA will take immediate steps to countermand all allocations which have been made to the MND.

Second, the storage conditions for a number of valuable machine tools are quite unsatisfactory. R. L. Kirchberg Program Officer 國史饭 Academia Historica
